maml:description.maml:para: Adding code elements (function, enum, class, DSC Resource, tests...) to a module's source.

Add-Sample is an helper function to invoke a plaster template built-in the Sampler module. With this function you can bootstrap your module project by adding classes, functions and associated tests, examples and configuration elements.

Specifies a sample component based on the Plaster templates embedded with this module. The available types of module elements are: - Classes: A sample of 4 classes with inheritence and how to manage the orders to avoid parsing errors. - ClassResource: A Class-Based DSC Resources showing some best practices including tests, Reasons, localized strings. - Composite: A DSC Composite Resource (a configuration block) packaged the right way to make sure it's visible by Get-DscResource. - Enum: An example of a simple Enum. - MofResource: A sample of a MOF-Based DSC Resource following the DSC Community practices. - PrivateFunction: A sample of a Private function (not exported from the module) and its test. - PublicCallPrivateFunctions: A sample of 2 functions where the exported one (public) calls the private one, with the tests. - PublicFunction: A sample public function and its test.

Destination of your module source root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Destination of your module source root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Specifies a sample component based on the Plaster templates embedded with this module. The available types of module elements are: - Classes: A sample of 4 classes with inheritence and how to manage the orders to avoid parsing errors. - ClassResource: A Class-Based DSC Resources showing some best practices including tests, Reasons, localized strings. - Composite: A DSC Composite Resource (a configuration block) packaged the right way to make sure it's visible by Get-DscResource. - Enum: An example of a simple Enum. - MofResource: A sample of a MOF-Based DSC Resource following the DSC Community practices. - PrivateFunction: A sample of a Private function (not exported from the module) and its test. - PublicCallPrivateFunctions: A sample of 2 functions where the exported one (public) calls the private one, with the tests. - PublicFunction: A sample public function and its test.

maml:alert.maml:para: This module requires and uses Plaster.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts an Hashtable to its string representation, recursively.
Convert an Hashtable to a string representation. For instance, this hashtable: @{a=1;b=2; c=3; d=@{dd='abcd'}} Becomes: a=1; b=2; c=3; d={dd=abcd}
Hashtable to convert to string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Hashtable to convert to string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: This command is not specific to Sampler projects, but is named that way to avoid conflict with other modules.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the module version from the module built by Sampler.

Will read the ModuleVersion and PrivateData.PSData.Prerelease tag of the Module Manifest that has been built by Sampler, by looking into the OutputDirectory where the Project's Module should have been built.
Output directory (usually as defined by the Project). By default it is set to 'output' in a Sampler project.

Sub folder where you want to build the Module to (instead of $OutputDirectory/$ModuleName). This is especially useful when you want to build DSC Resources, but you don't want the `Get-DscResource` command to find several instances of the same DSC Resources because of the overlapping $Env:PSmodulePath (`$buildRoot/output` for the built module and `$buildRoot/output/RequiredModules`).
In most cases I would recommend against setting $BuiltModuleSubdirectory.
Name of the Module to retrieve the version from its manifest (See Get-SamplerProjectName).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Whether the Module is built with its versioned Subdirectory, as you would see it on a System. For instance, if VersionedOutputDirectory is $true, the built module's ModuleBase would be: `output/MyModuleName/2.0.1/`

Sub folder where you want to build the Module to (instead of $OutputDirectory/$ModuleName). This is especially useful when you want to build DSC Resources, but you don't want the `Get-DscResource` command to find several instances of the same DSC Resources because of the overlapping $Env:PSmodulePath (`$buildRoot/output` for the built module and `$buildRoot/output/RequiredModules`).
In most cases I would recommend against setting $BuiltModuleSubdirectory.
Name of the Module to retrieve the version from its manifest (See Get-SamplerProjectName).
Output directory (usually as defined by the Project). By default it is set to 'output' in a Sampler project.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Whether the Module is built with its versioned Subdirectory, as you would see it on a System. For instance, if VersionedOutputDirectory is $true, the built module's ModuleBase would be: `output/MyModuleName/2.0.1/`

For MOF-based DSC Resources, look at the `Get-MofSchemaName` function.

Gets the absolute value of a path, that can be relative to another folder or the current Working Directory `$PWD` or Drive.
This function will resolve the Absolute value of a path, whether it's potentially relative to another path, relative to the current working directory, or it's provided with an absolute Path.
The Path does not need to exist, but the command will use the right [System.Io.Path]::DirectorySeparatorChar for the OS, and adjust the `..` and `.` of a path by removing parts of a path when needed.

Relative or Absolute Path to resolve, can also be $null/Empty and will return the RelativeTo absolute path. It can be Absolute but relative to the current drive: i.e. `/Windows` would resolve to `C:\Windows` on most Windows systems.
Path to prepend to $Path if $Path is not Absolute. If $RelativeTo is not absolute either, it will first be resolved using [System.Io.Path]::GetFullPath($RelativeTo) before being pre-pended to $Path.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Relative or Absolute Path to resolve, can also be $null/Empty and will return the RelativeTo absolute path. It can be Absolute but relative to the current drive: i.e. `/Windows` would resolve to `C:\Windows` on most Windows systems.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to prepend to $Path if $Path is not Absolute. If $RelativeTo is not absolute either, it will first be resolved using [System.Io.Path]::GetFullPath($RelativeTo) before being pre-pended to $Path.

maml:alert.maml:para: When the root drive is omitted on Windows, the path is not considered absolute. `Split-Path -IsAbsolute -Path '/src/`

maml:description.maml:para: Calculates or retrieves the version of the Repository.

Attempts to retrieve the version associated with the repository or the module within the repository. If the Version is not provided, the preferred way is to use GitVersion if available, but alternatively it will locate a module manifest in the source folder and read its version.
Path to the Module Manifest that should determine the version if GitVersion is not available.
Provide the Version to be splitted and do not rely on GitVersion or the Module's manifest.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to the Module Manifest that should determine the version if GitVersion is not available.
Provide the Version to be splitted and do not rely on GitVersion or the Module's manifest.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Get the ModuleBase of a module built with Sampler (directory where the module manifest is).

Based on a project's configuration of OutputDirectory, BuiltModuleSubdirectory, ModuleName and whether the built module is within a VersionedOutputDirectory; this function will resolve the expected ModuleBase of that Module.
Output directory (usually as defined by the Project). By default it is set to 'output' in a Sampler project.

Sub folder where you want to build the Module to (instead of $OutputDirectory/$ModuleName). This is especially useful when you want to build DSC Resources, but you don't want the `Get-DscResource` command to find several instances of the same DSC Resources because of the overlapping $Env:PSmodulePath (`$buildRoot/output` for the built module and `$buildRoot/output/RequiredModules`).
In most cases I would recommend against setting $BuiltModuleSubdirectory.
Name of the Module to retrieve the version from its manifest (See Get-SamplerProjectName).

Allows to specify a specific ModuleVersion to search the ModuleBase if known. If the ModuleVersion is not known but the VersionedOutputDirectory is set to $true, a wildcard (*) will be used so that the path can be resolved by Get-Item or similar commands.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Whether the Module is built with its versioned Subdirectory, as you would see it on a System. For instance, if VersionedOutputDirectory is $true, the built module's ModuleBase would be: `output/MyModuleName/2.0.1/`

Sub folder where you want to build the Module to (instead of $OutputDirectory/$ModuleName). This is especially useful when you want to build DSC Resources, but you don't want the `Get-DscResource` command to find several instances of the same DSC Resources because of the overlapping $Env:PSmodulePath (`$buildRoot/output` for the built module and `$buildRoot/output/RequiredModules`).
In most cases I would recommend against setting $BuiltModuleSubdirectory.
Name of the Module to retrieve the version from its manifest (See Get-SamplerProjectName).

Allows to specify a specific ModuleVersion to search the ModuleBase if known. If the ModuleVersion is not known but the VersionedOutputDirectory is set to $true, a wildcard (*) will be used so that the path can be resolved by Get-Item or similar commands.
Output directory (usually as defined by the Project). By default it is set to 'output' in a Sampler project.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Loads the PowerShell data file of a module manifest.

This function loads a psd1 (usually a module manifest), and return the hashtable. This implementation works around the issue where Windows PowerShell version have issues with the pwsh $Env:PSModulePath such as in vscode with the vscode powershell extension.
Path to the ModuleManifest to load. This will not use Import-Module because the module may not be finished building, and might be missing some information to make it a valid module manifest.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to the ModuleManifest to load. This will not use Import-Module because the module may not be finished building, and might be missing some information to make it a valid module manifest.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Gets the absolute ModuleRoot path (the psm1) of a module.
This function reads the module manifest (.psd1) and if the ModuleRoot property is defined, it will resolve its absolute path based on the ModuleManifest's Path.
If no ModuleRoot is defined, then this function will return $null.
The path (relative to the current working directory or absolute) to the ModuleManifest to read to find the ModuleRoot.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The path (relative to the current working directory or absolute) to the ModuleManifest to read to find the ModuleRoot.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Gets the Project Name based on the ModuleManifest if Available.
Finds the Module Manifest through `Get-SamplerProjectModuleManifest` and deduce ProjectName based on the BaseName of that manifest.
BuildRoot of the Sampler project to search the Module manifest from.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
BuildRoot of the Sampler project to search the Module manifest from.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Gets the project's source Path based on the ModuleManifest location.

By finding the ModuleManifest of the project using `Get-SamplerProjectModuleManifest` this function assumes that the source folder is the parent folder of that module manifest. This allows the source folder to be src, source, or the Module name's, without hardcoding the name.
BuildRoot of the Sampler project to search the Module manifest from.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
BuildRoot of the Sampler project to search the Module manifest from.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Executes git with the provided arguments.
This command executes git with the provided arguments and throws an error if the call failed.
Specifies the arguments to call git with. It is passes as an array of strings, e.g. @('tag', 'v2.0.0').
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the arguments to call git with. It is passes as an array of strings, e.g. @('tag', 'v2.0.0').
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Git does not throw an error that can be caught by the pipeline. For example this git command error but does not throw 'hello' as one would expect. ``` PS> try { git describe --contains } catch { throw 'hello' } fatal: cannot describe '144e0422398e89cc8451ebba738c0a410b628302' ``` So we have to determine if git worked or not by checking the last exit code and then throw an error to stop the pipeline.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Calls git to set user name in the git config.

maml:description.maml:para: Merge two JaCoCoReports into one.

When you run tests independently for the same module, you may want to get a unified report of all the code paths that were tested. For instance, you want to get a unified report when the runs where done on Linux and Windows.
This function helps merge the results of two runs into one file. If you have more than two reports, keep merging them.
One of the JaCoCoReports you would like to merge.
Second JaCoCoReports you would like to merge with the other one.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Second JaCoCoReports you would like to merge with the other one.
One of the JaCoCoReports you would like to merge.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: See also Update-JaCoCoStatistic that will update the counter elements. Thanks to Yorick (@ykuijs) for this great feature!

maml:description.maml:para: Create a module scaffolding and add samples & build pipeline.

New-SampleModule helps you bootstrap your PowerShell module project by creating a the folder structure of your module, and optionally add the pipeline files to help with compiling the module, publishing to PSGallery and GitHub and testing quality and style such as per the DSC Community guildelines.
The Custom PS repository if you want to use an internal (private) feed to pull for dependencies.

Destination of your module source root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files.
If you'd rather select specific features from this template to build your module, use this parameter instead.
Type of license you would like to add to your repository. We recommend MIT for Open Source projects.
The author of module that will be populated in the Module Manifest and will show in the Gallery.
The Description of your Module, to be used in your Module manifest.
The Name of your Module.
Version you want to set in your Module Manifest. If you follow our approach, this will be updated during compilation anyway.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
How you would like to call your Source repository to differentiate from the output and the tests folder. We recommend to call it 'source', and the default value is 'source'.
The Custom PS repository if you want to use an internal (private) feed to pull for dependencies.

Destination of your module source root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files.
Type of license you would like to add to your repository. We recommend MIT for Open Source projects.
The author of module that will be populated in the Module Manifest and will show in the Gallery.
The Description of your Module, to be used in your Module manifest.
The Name of your Module.
Specifies the type of module to create. The default value is 'SimpleModule'. Preset of module you would like to create: - CompleteSample - SimpleModule - SimpleModule_NoBuild - dsccommunity
Version you want to set in your Module Manifest. If you follow our approach, this will be updated during compilation anyway.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
How you would like to call your Source repository to differentiate from the output and the tests folder. We recommend to call it 'source', and the default value is 'source'.
The Custom PS repository if you want to use an internal (private) feed to pull for dependencies.

Destination of your module source root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files.
If you'd rather select specific features from this template to build your module, use this parameter instead.
Type of license you would like to add to your repository. We recommend MIT for Open Source projects.
The author of module that will be populated in the Module Manifest and will show in the Gallery.
The Description of your Module, to be used in your Module manifest.
The Name of your Module.
Specifies the type of module to create. The default value is 'SimpleModule'. Preset of module you would like to create: - CompleteSample - SimpleModule - SimpleModule_NoBuild - dsccommunity
Version you want to set in your Module Manifest. If you follow our approach, this will be updated during compilation anyway.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
How you would like to call your Source repository to differentiate from the output and the tests folder. We recommend to call it 'source', and the default value is 'source'.

maml:alert.maml:para: See Add-Sample to add elements such as functions (private or public), tests, DSC Resources to your project.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-SampleModule -DestinationPath . -ModuleType CompleteSample -ModuleAuthor "Gael Colas" -ModuleName MyModule -ModuleVersion 0.0.1 -ModuleDescription "a sample module" -LicenseType MIT -SourceDirectory Source

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new JaCoCo XML document based on the provided missed and hit lines.

Creates a new JaCoCo XML document based on the provided missed and hit lines. This command is usually used together with the output object from Pester that also have been passed through ModuleBuilder's Convert-LineNumber.
An array of PSCustomObject that contain all the missed code lines.
An array of PSCustomObject that contain all the code lines that were hit.
The name of package of the test source files, e.g. 'source', 'MyFunction', or '2.3.0'.
The display name of the package if it should be shown to the user differently, e.g. 'source' if the package name is '2.3.0'. Defaults to the same value as PackageName.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
An array of PSCustomObject that contain all the code lines that were hit.
An array of PSCustomObject that contain all the missed code lines.
The display name of the package if it should be shown to the user differently, e.g. 'source' if the package name is '2.3.0'. Defaults to the same value as PackageName.
The name of package of the test source files, e.g. 'source', 'MyFunction', or '2.3.0'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $pesterObject = Invoke-Pester ./tests/unit -CodeCoverage $pesterObject.CodeCoverage.MissedCommands | Convert-LineNumber -ErrorAction 'Stop' -PassThru | Out-Null $pesterObject.CodeCoverage.HitCommands | Convert-LineNumber -ErrorAction 'Stop' -PassThru | Out-Null New-SamplerJaCoCoDocument ` -MissedCommands $pesterObject.CodeCoverage.MissedCommands ` -HitCommands $pesterObject.CodeCoverage.HitCommands ` -PackageName 'source'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-SamplerJaCoCoDocument ` -MissedCommands @{ Class = 'ResourceBase' Function = 'Compare' HitCount = 0 SourceFile = '.\Classes\001.ResourceBase.ps1' SourceLineNumber = 4 } ` -HitCommands @{ Class = 'ResourceBase' Function = 'Compare' HitCount = 2 SourceFile = '.\Classes\001.ResourceBase.ps1' SourceLineNumber = 3 } ` -PackageName 'source'

maml:description.maml:para: Create a Sampler scaffolding so you can add samples & build pipeline.
New-SamplerPipeline helps you bootstrap your project pipeline, whether it's for a Chocolatey package, Azure Policy Guest Configuration packages or just a pipeline for a CI process.

Destination of your project's root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files such as build.ps1, the entry point.

Type of Pipeline you would like to create at the destination folder. You can create a base pipeline using th value `Build` that will include the bootstrap and resolve dependency process, but you will need to edit the `Build.Yaml` to call the tasks you desire. You can also create a Chocolatey pipeline, preconfigured to build Chocolatey packages, or call a Sampler pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Destination of your project's root folder, defaults to the current directory ".". We assume that your current location is the module folder, and within this folder we will find the source folder, the tests folder and other supporting files such as build.ps1, the entry point.

Type of Pipeline you would like to create at the destination folder. You can create a base pipeline using th value `Build` that will include the bootstrap and resolve dependency process, but you will need to edit the `Build.Yaml` to call the tasks you desire. You can also create a Chocolatey pipeline, preconfigured to build Chocolatey packages, or call a Sampler pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Other parameters will be displayed based on the Template used for the pipeline. See Add-Sample to add elements such as functions (private or public), tests, DSC Resources to your project.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-SamplerPipeline -DestinationPath . -Pipeline Build -ProjectName MyBuild -License 'true' -LicenseType MIT -SourceDirectory Source -MainGitBranch main -ModuleDescription 'some desc' -CustomRepo PSGallery -Features All

Parse a SemVer2 Version string.

This function parses a SemVer (semver.org) version string into an object with the following properties: - Version: The version without tag or metadata, as used by folder versioning in PowerShell modules.
- PreReleaseString: A Publish-Module compliant prerelease tag (see below).
- ModuleVersion: The Version and Prerelease tag compliant with Publish-Module.

For instance, this is a valid SemVer: `1.15.0-pr0224-0022+Sha.47ae45eb2cfed02b249f239a7c55e5c71b26ab76.Date.2020-01-07` The Metadata is stripped: `1.15.0-pr0224-0022` The Version is `1.15.0`. The prerelease tag is `-pr0224-0022` However, Publish-Module (or NuGet/PSGallery) does not support such pre-release, so this function only keep the first part `-pr0224`
Full SemVer version string with (optional) metadata and prerelease tag to be parsed.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Full SemVer version string with (optional) metadata and prerelease tag to be parsed.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Update the Statistics of a freshly merged JaCoCoReports.
When you merge two or several JaCoCoReports together using the Merge-JaCoCoReport, the calculated statistics of the Original document are not updated.
This Command will re-calculate the JaCoCo statistics and update the Document.
For the Package, Class, Method of all source files and the total it will update: - the Instruction Covered
- the Instruction Missed
- the Line Covered
- the Line Missed
- the Method Covered
- the Method Missed
